content.title: Duplex Ultrasound Velocity Criteria for Stenosis

statement.text: Duplex ultrasound velocity criteria use peak systolic velocity (PSV), end-diastolic velocity (EDV), and velocity ratios to grade arterial stenosis, with specific thresholds validated for carotid, renal, and peripheral arteries.
statement.formal: Key metrics: PSV, EDV, ICA/CCA ratio; Carotid 50-69%: PSV 125-230 cm/s; Carotid ≥70%: PSV >230 cm/s, EDV >100 cm/s; Velocity increases with stenosis severity

explanation.intuition: Blood flows faster through a narrowed artery, like water through a pinched garden hose. By measuring how fast blood moves at different points, we can estimate how severe the narrowing is.
explanation.key_insight: Peak systolic velocity is the primary metric - higher velocity = more severe stenosis. Ratios help correct for cardiac output variations.
explanation.technical_details: Duplex ultrasound combines B-mode imaging with pulsed Doppler to measure blood flow velocities at stenotic sites. The continuity equation predicts that velocity increases proportionally to the reduction in cross-sectional area. Peak systolic velocity (PSV) is the most reliable parameter for stenosis grading. End-diastolic velocity (EDV) adds specificity for severe stenosis. Velocity ratios (ICA/CCA for carotid) normalize for cardiac output variations.

definition.@value: Standardized duplex ultrasound velocity thresholds for grading arterial stenosis severity.

treatment: Intervention thresholds depend on vessel and symptoms

sources.reference: Society for Vascular Surgery Consensus Document on Carotid Duplex Criteria

learning_objectives: Apply velocity criteria to grade carotid stenosis
Explain the physiologic basis for velocity-stenosis relationship
clinical_pearls: Carotid ≥70%: PSV >230 cm/s AND EDV >100 cm/s
Near-occlusion paradox: very severe stenosis may have LOW velocity
